content: The Federal Employees Health Benefits (FEHB) Program offers private health insurance to federal employees, retirees, and their dependents, with over $40 billion in annual benefits. Approximately 8.2 million individuals are covered each year, with participation being voluntary. Coverage options include individual, family, and self plus one plans in fee-for-service (FFS) or health maintenance organizations (HMOs). Premiums are shared between the federal. In 2016, a new coverage option called self plus one was introduced for federal employees and their eligible family members under the FEHB Program. Plans are either fee-for-service (FFS) or health maintenance organizations (HMOs), with shared premiums between the government and employees. All plans cover basic services like hospital and physician care, with varying cost sharing. Prior to 1959, federal employees had to obtain health insurance independently or through limited union plans. Prior to the creation of FEHB in 1959, federal employees could not obtain health insurance through the government. Employers in the private sector started offering health insurance in 1950. President Truman's Commission recommended federal government health insurance in 1951. Congress passed the Federal Employees Health Benefits Act of 1959 (FEHBA) to establish eligibility and coverage options. The Federal Employees Health Benefits Act of 1959 (FEHBA) established parameters for health insurance coverage for federal employees, including eligibility, coverage options, and the government's share of premiums. It also created the Employees Health Benefits Fund and outlined the role of the Office of Personnel Management (OPM) in managing the program. FEHBA allows enrollees to choose between different coverage options offered by private insurers. FEHBA, enacted in 1959, established health insurance guidelines for federal employees. OPM has the authority to contract with insurers and regulate FEHB. While the basic model of FEHB remains the same, changes have been made to premium cost-sharing and eligibility. Congress plays a role in modifying FEHB through legislative authority. Since its inception in 1959, the Federal Employees Health Benefits (FEHB) program has undergone various modifications. Changes to the government's share of premiums, eligibility, services, and benefits have been made over time. Congress has a role in modifying FEHB through legislative authority. The program's model involves competing insurers offering coverage options to enrollees with minimal intervention from the Office of Personnel Management (OPM). This model is seen as successful in allowing enrollees to make cost-conscious choices. This model is viewed as successful in enabling enrollees to make cost-conscious choices and constrain overall cost growth. Researchers have explored exporting aspects of the FEHB model to other health care programs, such as Medicare, and expanding access to FEHB for individuals like small business employees or the uninsured. Policymakers have introduced legislation to create new programs or expand FEHB eligibility. Congressional interest in FEHB extends beyond its potential as a model for other programs, as Congress has a financial interest in its viability and sustainability.
